I think you've hit the nail on the head.

 

My approach is to isolate the method under test as much as possible.
However, calls to private methods don't lend themselves easily to being
factored out of the test.  I eliminate remote object method calls with
mocks, and local method calls (to public/protected methods of the same
class) by overriding them in an anonymous inner class declared in my test
method.  Obviously I can't override a private method.

 

I think the solution is to refactor the private method such that it can be
either eliminated (by extracting a public/protected parent method that can
be overriden) or tested along with the method under test (by supporting some
form of mock object injection).  

 

Does this sound reasonable?

 

-Mitch

--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> I understand you don't believe in polluting the public API,
> but saying that that suggestion won't solve the problem is
> ridiculous.
> [...]

Most often when I see this symptom -- a private method or something 
deep in the hierarchy failing, and preventing testing -- it's because 
the code I'm testing is using some external resource, such as a 
database, that really needs a Mock Object implementation for testing.

I don't have enough information to be sure that this is the proper 
advice, but in my experience, it's been a good guess.  (...until more 
detailed information becomes available.)
